STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 11, 2022
St Vincent Catholic Charities-Child Welfare
2800 West Willow
Lansing, MI 48917
RE: License #: CB330201019
St Vincent Catholic Charities-Child Welfare
2800 West Willow
Lansing, MI 48917
Dear Ms. Sepolen:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 4/21/22.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please indicate why the previous CAP did not correct the issue and what
changes will be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
One of one special evaluations did not have documentation that a copy of the report
was provided to the foster care worker.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child: (subsections a-j)
One of three case files had replacements that occurred in July and November 2021.
However, the file did not have documentation required by this rule.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/30/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/13/20
3/24/21 RENEWAL, CAP approved 4/21/21
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(6) Service plans shall be signed by the social services worker
and the social services supervisor.
Two of three case files (2 of 12 USPs) did not have signatures by the worker and
supervisor.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010,
continues to reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and
is managing expenditures.
Three of three IL files did not have monthly budgets on file as required.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(a) All of the following personal information pertaining to the
youth: (xii) A photograph updated on an annual basis.
4

Two of three IL files held photos that were over a year old.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Three of three IL files did not have documentation that contracts were reviewed and
provided to the youth every 90 days.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-3B Relative engagement and placement
Page 15
The DHS-3130A must be completed within the
timeframes described below:
• For emergency placements, within 30 calendar days of the
child’s placement in the relative home.
One of three case files held a relative caregiver assessment (3130A) that was not
completed within the required timeframe.
FOM 722-06I Maintaining connections: parenting time
Page 7 & 10
Families with children in foster care who have a goal of
reunification must have in-person parenting time unless an
approved exception exists... Caseworkers must record all
exceptions in MiSACWIS.
Caseworkers must document all reasonable efforts to ensure in
person parenting time in the case service plan.
One of three case files did not have sufficient documentation regarding attempts to
complete parenting time.
FOM 722-08 Case service plans
Page 11
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
5

Three of three case files each held one USP that was approved outside of the
required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as 722-09)
3/30/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/13/20
03/24/21 RENEWAL, CAP approved 4/21/21
FOM 722-06H Case contacts
Page 17
The caseworker must meet with their supervisor at least
monthly for case consultation on every assigned case. Monthly
case consultation may be conducted in person or by video
conference.
Two of three case files each had one missing supervision contact.
FOM 722-08D Treatment plans
Page 10
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Six of six foster care and independent living files had PATP signatures that were
missing or obtained outside of the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as 722-08C)
3/30/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/13/20
3/24/21 RENEWAL, CAP approved 4/21/21
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
Page 2-3
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
Two of three case files did not have medical passports updated or signed on a
quarterly basis.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/30/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/13/20
3/24/21 RENEWAL, CAP approved 4/21/21
FOM 801-01 Health requirements
Page 3-4
A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every six
months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
Documentation of the completed required medical (initial,
periodic, and yearly) and dental exams for children in foster care
must be entered into the Health Profile within MiSACWIS.
6

One of three case files did not have a six-month dental exam on file. The agency
reported the exam occurred on time, but they did not receive documentation from
the dental office. The agency did not document attempts to obtain the dental form.
FOM 722-08E Foster care/juvenile justice action summary
Page 2 & 6
Within three business days of change in caseworker or
organization, the new caseworker must document the following
for the former and new caseworker… (Page 2)
Within three business days of foster care or juvenile justice
program or case closure, the caseworker must
document…(Page 6)
(Page 2) Two of three independent living files had youth change placements.
However, the action summaries were not completed within the required timeframe.
(Page 6) Two of three foster care files did not have closing action summaries
completed within the required timeframe.
ADM 330 Adoption quarterly
Page 1
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report.
One of three adoption files did not have a quarterly update completed between June
and December 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/30/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/13/20
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 All PATP signatures are due within 30 days of the report period end date.
 Signatures should be obtained in person when possible. However, for parents
that are not responding, efforts to obtain the signature should be documented
in MiSACWIS within the 30-day time frame. If the signature is later obtained, it
should be uploaded with the previous efforts.
 Video-conference parenting time must be documented in MiSACWIS.
 Closing DHHS-69s must be completed within 3 days of case closure, or within
3 days of receiving the closing court order.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
7

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
A CAP, approved 4/21/2021, was implemented due to the 3/24/2021 renewal
evaluation. During this review, four repeat violations were found regarding PATP
signatures, medical passports, placement documentation, and service plan approval.
The agency acknowledged some difficulty in these areas due to staff shortages and
anticipates improvement over the next year now that staffing has become more
stable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA) report was reviewed on-site. The CAA
identified action steps and review for all areas of the 2021 CAP. Overall the agency
noted improvement in several areas, as compliance percentiles improved in the
monthly management report. The agency reported meeting with staff on a frequent
basis to discuss CAP items and implement new strategies with the assistance of a
quality improvement/compliance coordinator. The administrator identified some
challenges remain, due to being short staffed for several months. Currently the
agency has a small staff and therefore a smaller number of cases. Once staffing
increases, the agency will begin to accept more cases at a slow pace as to not
overwhelm themselves.
The agency acknowledged continued improvement is needed in service plan
timeframes, signatures, and uploading documents timely. The agency also reported
difficulty obtaining medical/dental paperwork from providers. They are currently
keeping a log of contacts to show their attempts to obtain this paperwork.
Interviews
Three staff interviews were completed. Staff reported there is a positive atmosphere
among co-workers and they are able to pull together when needed. Specifically,
during a staff shortage, staff were able to count on one another for help when feeling
overwhelmed. Staff reported their supervisors are very helpful, knowledgeable, and
able to keep everyone on track. Staff felt confident their supervisors kept them up to
date on policy/procedure changes as they happened. Staff reported the agency
focused on the CAP a lot over the past year and met frequently about specific areas.
The only concern reported by staff is the lack of a program manager at this time, and
the strain it put on the supervisors to cover the workload the program manager
would normally carry.
VII. FIELD ANALYST
The DCWL Analyst identified one safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert:
8

An unlicensed relative caregiver had water-stained ceiling tiles, due to a water leak
from the upstairs bathroom. The bathroom sink is the suspected source of the leak.
The water to the sink was turned off prior to the analyst’s visit.
Resolution:
The agency was aware of the issue and previously requested a quote from the
relative, in order to access FIG funds and financially assist with the repair. The
relative obtained a quote for a roof repair. However, a leak investigation determined
the roof was not the issue, and repair was needed at the bathroom sink. The relative
replaced the stained ceiling tiles and obtained one quote for the sink repair. As FIG
requires two repair quotes, the agency continued to request a second quote from the
caregiver. However, the caregiver reported having difficulty obtaining a second
quote, despite assistance from the agency. A referral was provided to the caregiver
for community resources to assist with the repair. The caregiver has since become
non-responsive to the agency regarding this issue. The agency verified during a
home visit that a second bathroom is available in the home. Family members also
use the bathtub faucet in the affected bathroom, for hand washing. As the water to
the broken sink is turned off and no longer leaking, and the family has access to
water in that bathroom and has access to a second bathroom, the agency
determined this is no longer a safety issue. However, they will continue working with
the relative to obtain FIG funds.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue
on a regular license.
_ ______________May 9, 2022____________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 11, 2022
